q.content: If (x_n) and (y_n) are Cauchy sequences, then one easy way to prove that (x_n + y_n) is Cauchy is to use the Cauchy Criterion. By Theorem 2.6.4, (x_n) and (y_n) must be convergent, and the Algebraic Limit Theorem then implies (x_n + y_n) is convergent and hence Cauchy.
Give an example of each of the following, or argue that such a request is impossible.

a.content:
Since (x_n) \rightarrow x, by definition of convergence, for all \epsilon there exists N such that N < n \Rightarrow |x_n - x | < \epsilon.

Let's say there's also m that is bigger than N. That means

\begin {aligned} & |x_m - x| < \epsilon \\ & \Rightarrow |x - x_m| < \epsilon \\ & \Rightarrow |x - x_m| + |x_n - x| < 2\epsilon \end {aligned}

And because of triangle equality

\begin {aligned} & \Rightarrow |x - x_m + x_n - x| = |x_n - x_m| < |x - x_m| + |x_n - x| < 2\epsilon \end {aligned}
